content.description: Climb the overhanging face covered with shallow huecos to a highball finish.
content.protection: A crash pad or two and a spotter. Mind the block on the left side of the landing.
content.location:
This is NW of the small parking area ~130 yards, east and slightly downhill of

V4

.  There is a placard at bottom of boulder with "V5-" written on it.

content.description: A fun little problem coming out of the cave on the east face of the V5 boulder. Sit start at good crimps and throw up and right using diagonal edges and then left to a cruxy pinch. An interesting throw-into-mantle move guards the top.
content.protection: A pad and spotter. The landing is a little sketch.
content.location: Find the striking NW face that holds the V5- problem (which is more like V4...) hike around climbers left of this massive boulder and find this line coming out of the cave. There is an obvious mantle move at the top.

content.description:
This is somewhat of an eliminate problem but still a very good line.

The pic of this problem has a box around the two crimps that you eliminate using.

Start the same as for an Unknown V5 (the only other line established) - in a sidepull pocket and on a small slope. Go up to a big hueco with your right hand, left hand still in the sidepull, and then crossover bump to a full pad crimp. Lock off hard, use the intermediate pinch or go right to the small crimp with your left hand (stay tight, contain the swing). Up again to a weird divot, drop into a sidepull/undercling and go big up to the big pocket. Finish up same as the V5.
content.location: It is NW of the small parking area by ~130 yards.

content.description: This is a great problem that requires some good body tension and some tough skin. Sit start and pull to the stuck chockstone. From here, throw to a decent pinch and work your way up some powerful moves.
content.location: This is on the overhung backside of the V5- Boulder. The chalk is very obvious if approaching this boulder from the Large Diamond Boulder.
